articles.snippet: Last week they set off a firestorm at the University of Notre Dame. Why does this item of clothing get people so riled up?
articles.lead_paragraph: When did leggings make the leap from garment to cultural lightning rod? For what are essentially stretchy footless tights in a seemingly endless array of patterns and colors, they have been an unexpected source of controversy.
articles.abstract: Last week they set off a firestorm at the University of Notre Dame. Why does this item of clothing get people so riled up?

headline.main: It’s Possible Leggings Are the Future. Deal With It.
headline.print_headline: A Breaking Point For Stretchy Pants?

articles.snippet: People watched with horror as a fire consumed the spire and roof of Paris’s famed cathedral, and expressed despair that one of the city’s grandest cultural symbols was being damaged.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fire that tore through the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris on Monday, causing the collapse of its central spire and much of its roof, generated an outpouring of grief in France and around the world as the symbol of French culture and history burned.
articles.abstract: People watched with horror as a fire consumed the spire and roof of Paris’s famed cathedral, and expressed despair that one of the city’s grandest cultural symbols was being damaged.

headline.main: Fire at Notre-Dame Cathedral Leads to Expressions of Heartbreak Across the World
headline.print_headline: Heart of ‘My Country Is Being Gutted’

byline.original: By Sona Patel and Alan Yuhas

articles.snippet: Built in the 12th and 13th centuries, the cathedral is a jewel of medieval Gothic architecture.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Cathedral of Notre-Dame, where a large fire broke out on Monday evening, is among the most famous landmarks in Paris, drawing about 13 million visitors a year.
articles.abstract: Built in the 12th and 13th centuries, the cathedral is a jewel of medieval Gothic architecture.

headline.main: Notre-Dame Cathedral: Facts and a Brief History

byline.original: By Karen Zraick and Heather Murphy

articles.snippet: As hundreds of firefighters raced to the cathedral, in the center of the French capital, Parisians gathered to watch, many of them in tears.
articles.lead_paragraph: A devastating fire swept through Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris Monday evening, severely damaging one of the city’s most storied landmarks and one of the Catholic world’s most sacred sites.
articles.abstract: As hundreds of firefighters raced to the cathedral, in the center of the French capital, Parisians gathered to watch, many of them in tears.

headline.main: Despair and Grief Amid the Smoke and Flames of Notre-Dame

articles.snippet: Video filmed by onlookers showed flames and smoke billowing from the building. The cathedral was evacuated, and the fire’s cause was not known.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Notre-Dame cathedral, the symbol of the beauty and history of Paris, was scarred by an extensive fire on Monday evening that caused its delicate spire to collapse, bruised the Parisian skies with smoke and further disheartened a city already back on its heels after weeks of violent protests.
articles.abstract: Video filmed by onlookers showed flames and smoke billowing from the building. The cathedral was evacuated, and the fire’s cause was not known.

headline.main: Fire Mauls Beloved Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris
headline.print_headline: Fire Mauls Paris’s Beloved Notre-Dame

byline.original: By Adam Nossiter and Aurelien Breeden

articles.snippet: A hundred years from now, people will still be talking about the fire of 2019.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — I learned that Notre-Dame was burning on Monday night when a stranger — an older man — stopped me on the street. A shrieking ambulance had just sped past us. He pointed to a plume of smoke in the distance, and said: “It’s going to Notre-Dame. Notre-Dame is on fire.”
articles.abstract: A hundred years from now, people will still be talking about the fire of 2019.

headline.main: We Were the Caretakers of Notre-Dame. We Failed.

articles.snippet: It was the 12th century, and the architects behind a cathedral rising in the heart of Paris wanted to make a statement.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the architects of Cathedral of Notre-Dame set to work some 850 years ago, their goals were nothing if not ambitious.
articles.abstract: It was the 12th century, and the architects behind a cathedral rising in the heart of Paris wanted to make a statement.

headline.main: Pictures of Notre-Dame Before the Fire: A Cathedral That Defined a City

articles.snippet: A Paris Fire Department chaplain was among those who rushed into a burning Notre-Dame to save artworks, artifacts and relics.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — By the time the Paris Fire Department’s chaplain made his way inside Notre-Dame, flames had already consumed most of the cathedral’s roof and its spire had smashed onto the nave.
articles.abstract: A Paris Fire Department chaplain was among those who rushed into a burning Notre-Dame to save artworks, artifacts and relics.

headline.main: The Chaplain, the Cathedral Fire and the Race to Rescue Notre-Dame’s Relics
headline.print_headline: Racing Against Flames, Chaplain Led Rescue of Cathedral’s Sacred Artifacts

headline.main: Black Churches Destroyed by Arson See Spike in Donations After Notre-Dame Fire
headline.print_headline: Surge in Online Donations  For Fire-Ravaged Churches

byline.original: By Karen Zraick and Niraj Chokshi

articles.snippet: Sacred symbol, tourist attraction, beacon for visitors and locals alike: After the fire, writers reflect on the building that has been both constant and ever-shifting in the life of Paris.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’m embarrassed by the thought of it now, nearly 30 years later: me busking in the shadow of Notre-Dame, guitar case open for donations as I belted out Bob Dylan and Neil Young songs. I was awful, yet another contributor to a particular strain of noise pollution that has degraded the quality of life in European city centers at least since Bob Marley’s “Exodus” came out. But back then you could make a lot of money in Paris if you sang with a bona fide American accent. So, that’s what I did night after night, planting myself at the edge of the cathedral’s tourist-choked parvis and parlaying an eight-song repertoire from the Liberal Arts College Songbook into a not-insignificant revenue stream.
articles.abstract: Sacred symbol, tourist attraction, beacon for visitors and locals alike: After the fire, writers reflect on the building that has been both constant and ever-shifting in the life of Paris.

headline.main: Paris’s Cathedral of Imagination and Memory
headline.print_headline: Paris’s Cathedral of Imagination and Memory

articles.snippet: Many of the Christian artifacts in the cathedral have been saved, said France’s culture minister. But there are grave concerns about art and its acclaimed organ.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fire that destroyed two-thirds of the roof of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris on Monday did more than damage a beloved historic landmark: It also endangered the vast collection of Christian relics and artworks housed in the building and on its grounds.
articles.abstract: Many of the Christian artifacts in the cathedral have been saved, said France’s culture minister. But there are grave concerns about art and its acclaimed organ.

headline.main: Fate of Priceless Cultural Treasures Uncertain After Notre-Dame Fire

byline.original: By Alex Marshall, Liam Stack and Heather Murphy

articles.snippet: Workers were making repairs to the roof of Notre Dame on a fine April day. A fire broke out, too high to be quickly doused with water. That happened 140 years ago, in Indiana.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers were making repairs to the roof of Notre Dame on a fine April day. A fire broke out, too high to be quickly doused with water, and onlookers could only stare in disbelief as the building was consumed by flames.
articles.abstract: Workers were making repairs to the roof of Notre Dame on a fine April day. A fire broke out, too high to be quickly doused with water. That happened 140 years ago, in Indiana.

headline.main: Notre Dame, the University, Was Once Devastated by Fire, Too

byline.original: By Larry Buchanan, Weiyi Cai, James Glanz, Mika Gröndahl, Evan Grothjan, Allison McCann, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Karthik Patanjali, Jugal K. Patel, Scott Reinhard, Bedel Saget, Anjali Singhvi and Jeremy White

articles.snippet: How a burning cathedral rebukes a divided Catholic Church.
articles.lead_paragraph: A first draft of this column was written before flames engulfed the Cathedral of Notre-Dame de Paris, before its spire fell in one of the most dreadful live images since Sept. 11, 2001, before a blazing fire went further than any of France’s anticlerical revolutionaries ever dared.
articles.abstract: How a burning cathedral rebukes a divided Catholic Church.

headline.main: From the Ashes of Notre-Dame

articles.snippet: Paris — and the world — comes together after a devastating fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the joys of living in Paris has been to hear the tolling of the great bells of Notre-Dame on Easter Sunday, their festive peals echoing through elegant streets festooned with the blooms of spring. The bells survived what is likely to become known as the Great Fire of 2019, thank Heaven. But they have fallen silent.
articles.abstract: Paris — and the world — comes together after a devastating fire.

headline.main: Notre-Dame’s Bells Will Toll Again
headline.print_headline: Notre-Dame’s Bells Will Toll Again

articles.lead_paragraph: Notre-Dame, the 12th-century French cathedral damaged by fire on Monday, is the biggest architectural attraction in Paris, drawing about 13 million visitors per year to admire its Gothic architecture and stained glass.
articles.abstract: Share your reflections about Notre-Dame, Paris’s most visited architectural attraction, which was damaged by fire on Monday.

headline.main: What Does Notre-Dame Cathedral Mean to You?

articles.snippet: Days after a fire coursed through the Paris cathedral and donors pledged about $950 million, the French government announced measures to restore the monument.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Days after a fire tore through Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris, France started on Wednesday to focus on reconstruction, with President Emmanuel Macron having set the ambitious goal of rebuilding the Gothic landmark within five years and donations pouring in from around the world.
articles.abstract: Days after a fire coursed through the Paris cathedral and donors pledged about $950 million, the French government announced measures to restore the monument.

articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For years, restoration experts worried that the fragile copper figures risked plunging to earth from Notre-Dame cathedral’s 19th-century spire.
articles.abstract: Sculptures of the Twelve Apostles and four evangelists had been removed from the cathedral for restoration just days before the fire in Paris on Monday.

articles.snippet: To preserve the landmark cathedral’s design, officials chose not to install some fire-suppression systems features like firewalls and sprinklers.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Inside the cavernous cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris, the last Mass of the day was underway on Monday of Holy Week when the first fire alarm went off. It was 6:20 p.m., 25 minutes before the heavy wooden doors were scheduled to close to visitors for the day.
articles.abstract: To preserve the landmark cathedral’s design, officials chose not to install some fire-suppression systems features like firewalls and sprinklers.

headline.main: Notre-Dame Attic Was Known as ‘the Forest.’ And It Burned Like One.

articles.snippet: A fire tore the legendary Cathedral of Notre-Dame. Now, France’s president has called for it to be rebuilt in five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: A fire tore the legendary Cathedral of Notre-Dame. Now, France’s president has called for it to be rebuilt in five years.
articles.abstract: A fire tore the legendary Cathedral of Notre-Dame. Now, France’s president has called for it to be rebuilt in five years.

articles.snippet: The man who oversaw the design of the fire safety system at the cathedral said he was “stunned” at the fire’s speed. Experts said the system included delays that cost firefighters critical minutes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The architect who oversaw the design of the fire safety system at Notre-Dame acknowledged that officials had misjudged how quickly a flame would ignite and spread through the cathedral, resulting in a much more devastating blaze than they had anticipated.
articles.abstract: The man who oversaw the design of the fire safety system at the cathedral said he was “stunned” at the fire’s speed. Experts said the system included delays that cost firefighters critical minutes.

headline.main: Notre-Dame’s Safety Planners Underestimated the Risk, With Devastating Results

byline.original: By Katrin Bennhold and James Glanz

articles.snippet: The discussions gained strength as President Emmanuel Macron and other leaders paid tribute to the firefighters who saved the cathedral from complete destruction this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The ashes have barely settled from the devastating fire that tore through the Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris, but even as France paid tribute on Thursday to the firefighters who saved the structure and its relics, there was a growing debate about how the Gothic landmark should be rebuilt.
articles.abstract: The discussions gained strength as President Emmanuel Macron and other leaders paid tribute to the firefighters who saved the cathedral from complete destruction this week.

The fire that broke out at Notre-Dame this week is a historic event of our times.

articles.lead_paragraph: Reader reactions to the fire at Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris have ranged from outrage at the French government, which some readers say neglected to take proper care of the vulnerable icon, to foreboding, after another great symbol of sanctuary in the world was almost destroyed.

headline.main: Surveying the Damage to Notre-Dame, and to Ourselves

byline.original: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak

articles.snippet: A look at a blaze that ravaged a symbol of Paris, prompted calls for people to unite in restoring it and spurred inquiries into how such a catastrophe could have been prevented.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fire that ravaged Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris on Monday left a scarred skyline that one of the French capital’s most iconic structures has graced for centuries. Gone is the cathedral’s soaring, delicate 300-foot spire, which collapsed in the flames. The cathedral’s wooden roof is now blackened and charred.
articles.abstract: A look at a blaze that ravaged a symbol of Paris, prompted calls for people to unite in restoring it and spurred inquiries into how such a catastrophe could have been prevented.

headline.main: A Guide to Our Notre-Dame Fire Coverage

articles.snippet: France’s dazzling heritage in stone has proved both beautiful and burdensome for the state, and well beyond its means to maintain.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Even though it was one of France’s most iconic sites, Notre-Dame cathedral suffered years of neglect and struggled to find the millions it needed for urgent renovations before it was ravaged by fire. But France is replete with tens of thousands of other historic monuments, both beautiful and burdensome, including 86 other cathedrals that are all at risk.
articles.abstract: France’s dazzling heritage in stone has proved both beautiful and burdensome for the state, and well beyond its means to maintain.

headline.main: Notre-Dame: A Calamity Threatening to Be Repeated Across France
headline.print_headline: A Trove of Heritage In France, but a Dearth Of Money to Protect It

articles.snippet: The building’s three organists feared that the instrument had been lost in the fire that destroyed the roof and spire. They can’t wait to play it again.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the evening of April 15, Olivier Latry, one of the world’s greatest organists, arrived at a hotel in Vienna ahead of a planned concert.
articles.abstract: The building’s three organists feared that the instrument had been lost in the fire that destroyed the roof and spire. They can’t wait to play it again.

headline.main: Notre-Dame Musicians Rejoice That Cathedral’s Organ Was Spared
headline.print_headline: For Notre-Dame Organists, a Bit of Solace

articles.snippet: Mountaineers have been called in to install a giant tarp, a dangerous job not just because of the cathedral’s height, but also because the fire left the building unstable.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — With rain expected in Paris later this week, workers at Notre-Dame cathedral on Tuesday scrambled to protect the building’s interior, scaling the walls with ropes to put in place giant tarpaulin coverings, the cathedral’s chief architect said.
articles.abstract: Mountaineers have been called in to install a giant tarp, a dangerous job not just because of the cathedral’s height, but also because the fire left the building unstable.

headline.main: Notre-Dame, Ravaged by Fire, Faces a New Threat: Rain
headline.print_headline: Workers Rush to Protect Notre-Dame’s Interior Before It Rains

articles.snippet: I knew I’d never sound like a native. But shouldn’t I be much better than this?
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Notre-Dame burst into flames, I turned on the French TV news and realized that I had little vocabulary for either fires or churches. Whole sentences about collapsing spires were unintelligible to me.
articles.abstract: I knew I’d never sound like a native. But shouldn’t I be much better than this?

headline.main: Why It’s So Hard to Learn French in Middle Age

articles.lead_paragraph: On April 23, about a week after the fire at Notre-Dame in Paris, the designer Mathieu Lehanneur unveiled his plan for a new spire for the cathedral: a gleaming, 300-foot flame, made of carbon fiber and covered in gold leaf, that would be a permanent reminder of the tragedy.
articles.abstract: Plans for the restoration of the Paris cathedral have begun appearing online even before an official contest opens. Some have been received more kindly than others.

headline.main: How Notre-Dame Was Saved: 5 Things We Know

byline.original: By Elian Peltier, James Glanz, Mika Gröndahl, Weiyi Cai, Adam Nossiter and Liz Alderman

articles.snippet: A French environmental group alleges that officials did not warn the public about the dangerous levels of lead released during the Notre-Dame fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French environmental group has filed suit over what it says was the government’s delayed response to the large-scale release of lead into the atmosphere during the Notre-Dame fire.
articles.abstract: A French environmental group alleges that officials did not warn the public about the dangerous levels of lead released during the Notre-Dame fire.

headline.main: Notre-Dame Fire Released Toxic Lead That Authorities Dismissed, Lawsuit Says
headline.print_headline: Suit Over Blaze At Notre-Dame Faults Officials For Lead Risk

articles.snippet: Officials had shut down the work site over concerns about lead contamination. While stricter decontamination measures are now in place, concerns over safety persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Construction resumed at the Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris on Monday, weeks after authorities had shut the site down over worries about lead contamination linked to the fire in April.
articles.abstract: Officials had shut down the work site over concerns about lead contamination. While stricter decontamination measures are now in place, concerns over safety persist.

headline.main: Notre-Dame Construction Resumes in Paris, but Worries About Lead Remain
headline.print_headline: At Notre-Dame, Stricter Policies for Lead Cleanup

articles.snippet: Every expert consulted by The New York Times said it was still safe to visit Paris, though they differed on what precautions should be taken.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fire at Notre-Dame in April destroyed the cathedral’s roof and spire, which were covered with 460 tons of lead tiles. Tiny particles of some of that lead mixed with the plume of smoke that drifted over Paris.
articles.abstract: Every expert consulted by The New York Times said it was still safe to visit Paris, though they differed on what precautions should be taken.

headline.main: What We Found About Notre-Dame’s Lead, and What It May Mean for You
headline.print_headline: How Dangerous Is Paris After the Cathedral Fire?

byline.original: By Elian Peltier and James Glanz

articles.snippet: A contractor’s test at an apartment near the cathedral and law enforcement measurements at Police Headquarters both found levels far above safety guidelines, an environmental group revealed.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Months after fire engulfed Notre-Dame and the 460 tons of lead on its roof and spire, alarming levels of lead are still being found after decontamination efforts, including at the Paris Police Headquarters — raising new concerns that the authorities have not fully tackled the problem.
articles.abstract: A contractor’s test at an apartment near the cathedral and law enforcement measurements at Police Headquarters both found levels far above safety guidelines, an environmental group revealed.

headline.main: High Lead Levels Still Being Found Near Notre-Dame
headline.print_headline: Despite Cleanup, High Levels of Lead Contamination Are Found Near Notre-Dame

articles.snippet: The World Monuments Fund’s biennial selection of 25 at-risk cultural heritage sites also includes Easter Island in Chile and the Sacred Valley of the Incas in Peru.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Notre-Dame de Paris, which suffered a devastating fire earlier this year, and Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, which is the subject of a legal battle with implications for the future of protected public lands across the United States, have been named to the 2020 World Monuments Watch, a biennial list of cultural heritage sites that are in urgent need of conservation.
articles.abstract: The World Monuments Fund’s biennial selection of 25 at-risk cultural heritage sites also includes Easter Island in Chile and the Sacred Valley of the Incas in Peru.

headline.main: Bears Ears and Notre-Dame Named to 2020 World Monuments Watch

articles.abstract: The Paris cathedral, which suffered a devastating fire this year, is still closed to the public as reconstruction efforts slowly get underway.
articles.snippet: The Paris cathedral, which suffered a devastating fire this year, is still closed to the public as reconstruction efforts slowly get underway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris will not hold Christmas services this week for the first time in over two centuries, as workers continue to shore up the fragile building after a devastating fire.

headline.main: Notre-Dame Will Not Host Christmas Mass, a First in More Than 200 Years
headline.print_headline: Repairs Push Christmas Mass Out of Notre-Dame
